channel.title: Java Homework Help Needed
channel.description:
So I received this assignment from my Instructor and I am having a hard time wrapping my mind around it and getting it to work. Not sure how much of you guys are willing to help, but I hope that some one can successfully code it so I could look at it and study it and see how it was done.
We are using Eclipse to code.
[CODE]The Ford vs. Chevy car race
Our two cars begin the race at the starting gate “square 1” of 70 squares. Each square represents a possible position along the race course. The finish line is at square 70. The first car to reach or pass square 70 is the winner. There is a clock that ticks once per second and with each tick the computer should adjust the position of the cars.
After each tick of the clock, display each car’s position on the course. The amount to move a car should be determined by generating a random number between 1 and 10 and applying it as follows;
FOR FORD [INDENT]If the number is between 1 and 5 move forward 3 spots. If the number is between 6 and 8 move back 2 spots If the number is 9 do nothing If the number is 10 move forward 5 spots[/INDENT]
FOR CHEVY [INDENT]If the number is 1 move forward 5 spots If the number is 2 do nothing If the number is between 3 and 5 move back 2 spots If the number is between 6 and 10 move forward 3 spots[/INDENT]
For each tick of the clock (i.e. each repetition of the loop), print a 70 position line and show the position of the Ford and Chevy cars by placing a F and C at their respective positions. Occasionally both cars will be on the same space and when this happens you should print “2 car pileup”.
After printing each line, check to see if either car has reached or passed space 70. If this has happened, terminate the program and print which car won.
Be sure to document your code with comments.[/CODE]
Again, if some one could do the coding for this successful, that would be great! Thanks!

item.title: Java Homework Help Needed
item.dc:creator: @Elip007 Elip007
item.description:
@Elip007 wrote:

No trouble, just had to think it through for a bit.
After sitting down and fully taking the coding apart, I now fully understand how it all works.

Again I want to thank each and everyone that has helped me on this assignment! With out you guys, I would be stuck and confused. Thanks!

item.title: Java Homework Help Needed
item.dc:creator: @imthenull imthenull
item.description:
@imthenull wrote:

Switch statements aren’t faster is most cases, my code is shorter and imo easier to read. Just an alternative

Read full topic

item.title: Java Homework Help Needed
item.dc:creator: @Yesteryear Yesteryear
item.description:
@Yesteryear wrote:

[quote=“imthenull, post:3, topic:479084”][quote author=Yesteryear link=topic=597298.msg4205557#msg4205557 date=1358889578]

private static int getStepChevy(int num) {
	switch (num) {
	case 1:
		return 5;
	case 2:
		return 0;
	case 3:
	case 4:
	case 5:
		return 2;
	case 6:
	case 7:
	case 8:
	case 9:
	case 10:
		return 3;
	}
	return -1;
}

[/quote]
Sometimes switch statements are ugly and fail

if (num == 1) return 5; else if (num == 2) return 0; else if (num >= 3 && num <= 5) return 2; else if (num >= 6 && num <= 10) return 3; else return -1;

@OP tl;dr[/quote]
That’s just a matter of personal preference. Though my code is a good example of the saying: first make it work, then make it fast.

Read full topic

item.title: Java Homework Help Needed
item.dc:creator: @imthenull imthenull
item.description:
@imthenull wrote:

[quote=“Yesteryear, post:2, topic:479084”] private static int getStepChevy(int num) { switch (num) { case 1: return 5; case 2: return 0; case 3: case 4: case 5: return 2; case 6: case 7: case 8: case 9: case 10: return 3; } return -1; } [/quote]
Sometimes switch statements are ugly and fail

if (num == 1) return 5; else if (num == 2) return 0; else if (num >= 3 && num <= 5) return 2; else if (num >= 6 && num <= 10) return 3; else return -1;

@OP tl;dr

item.title: Java Homework Help Needed
item.dc:creator: @Yesteryear Yesteryear
item.description:
@Yesteryear wrote:

I don’t want to spoonfeed too much, but this should be somewhat the base.

public class Match {

	/**
	 * Returns amount of steps for a Ford.
	 * 
	 * @param num
	 *            a random value.
	 * @return the amount of steps.
	 */
	private static int getStepFord(int num) {
		switch (num) {
		case 1:
		case 2:
		case 3:
		case 4:
		case 5:
			return 3;
		case 6:
		case 7:
		case 8:
			return 2;
		case 9:
			return 0;
		case 10:
			return 5;

		}
		return -1;
	}

	/**
	 * Returns amount of steps for a Chevy.
	 * 
	 * @param num
	 *            a random value.
	 * @return the amount of steps.
	 */
	private static int getStepChevy(int num) {
		switch (num) {
		case 1:
			return 5;
		case 2:
			return 0;
		case 3:
		case 4:
		case 5:
			return 2;
		case 6:
		case 7:
		case 8:
		case 9:
		case 10:
			return 3;

		}
		return -1;
	}

	/**
	 * @param args
	 */
	public static void main(String[] args) {
		int posChevy = 0;
		int posFord = 0;

		Random rand = new Random();

		while (true) {

			// calculates next random value
			int randFord = rand.nextInt(9) + 1;
			int randChevy = rand.nextInt(9) + 1;

			// gets next amount of steps.
			int stepFord = getStepFord(randFord);
			
			// check
			if (stepFord == -1) {
				System.out.println("Critical error: impossible random value.");
				break;
			}

			// increments position of ford.
			posFord += stepFord;

			// checks if ford has won
			if (posFord >= 70) {
				System.out.println("The Ford has won.");
				break;
			}

			// gets next amount of steps
			int stepChevy = getStepChevy(randChevy);
			
			// check
			if (stepChevy == -1) {
				System.out.println("Critical error: impossible random value.");
				break;
			}

			// increments position of chevy.
			posChevy += stepChevy;

			// checks if chevy has won
			if (posChevy >= 70) {
				System.out.println("The Chevy has won.");
				break;
			}

			System.out.println("Ford: " + posFord);
			System.out.println("Chevy: " + posChevy);

			// sleep 1 second.
			try {
				Thread.sleep(1000);
			} catch (InterruptedException e) {
				e.printStackTrace();
			}
		}

	}
}

Read full topic

So I received this assignment from my Instructor and I am having a hard time wrapping my mind around it and getting it to work.
